==Education==
Bodmer was educated at [[Manchester Grammar School]] and went on to study the [[Mathematical Tripos]] at the [[University of Cambridge]] as a student of [[Clare College, Cambridge]]. He was awarded his [[PhD]] in 1959 from Cambridge for research on [[population genetics]] in the [[house mouse]] and ''[[Primula vulgaris]]'' (primrose) supervised by [[Ronald Fisher]].<ref name=mathgene/>

==Career and research==
In 1961 Bodmer joined [[Joshua Lederberg]]'s laboratory in the Genetics Department of [[Stanford University]] as a [[postdoctoral researcher]], continuing his work on [[population genetics]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://forum.stanford.edu/wiki/index.php/Early_Computers_at_Stanford|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140813185609/http://forum.stanford.edu/wiki/index.php/Early_Computers_at_Stanford|archivedate=2014-08-13|title=Early Computers at Stanford|publisher=Stanford University}}</ref> In 1962 Walter Bodmer was appointed to the faculty at Stanford. He left Stanford University in 1970 to become the first Professor of Genetics at the [[University of Oxford]] [http://www.hertford.ox.ac.uk/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=490&Itemid=581].<ref>Conversation with Walter Bodmer, San Francisco, 4 Dec.2010</ref>

Bodmer developed models for [[population genetics]] and worked on the [[human leukocyte antigen]] system and the use of [[somatic cell]] [[Hybrid (biology)|hybrids]] for human [[Genetic linkage|linkage]] studies. In 1985 he chaired a [[Royal Society]] committee which wrote ''The Bodmer Report''; this has been credited{{by whom|date=October 2015}} with starting the movement for the [[Public awareness of science|public understanding of science]].<ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019050128/http://royalsociety.org/WorkArea/DownloadAsset.aspx?id=5971|url=http://royalsociety.org/WorkArea/DownloadAsset.aspx?id=5971|publisher=Royal Society|title=Public Understanding of Science, 1985|archivedate=2013-10-19}}</ref>

Bodmer was one of the first to suggest the idea of the [[Human Genome Project]].<ref name=hugo>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150408001521/http://www.hugo-international.org/abt_hugopresidents.php|archivedate=2015-04-08|title=HUGO presidents|url=http://www.hugo-international.org/abt_hugopresidents.php}}</ref> In 1987 he received the [[Ellison-Cliffe Lecture|Ellison-Cliffe Medal]] from the [[Royal Society of Medicine]]. He was the director of research (1979–1991) and then [[Director General]] (1991–1996) of the [[Imperial Cancer Research Fund]]. He was also [[Chancellor (education)|Chancellor]] of the [[University of Salford]], [[England]] (1995–2005; succeeded by [[Martin Harris (academic)|Sir Martin Harris]]) and [[Principal (university)|Principal]] of [[Hertford College, Oxford]] (1996–2005; succeeded by [[John Landers|Dr. John Landers]]).

In 2005, Bodmer was appointed to lead a £2.3 million project (roughly 4.5 million USD) by the [[Wellcome Trust]] at [[University of Oxford]] to examine the genetic makeup of the [[United Kingdom]] - the [[People of the British Isles]] project. He was joined by Oxford Professor [[Peter Donnelly]] (a population genetics and statistics expert) and the Wellcome Trust Principal Research Fellow Lon Cardon. Bodmer said ''"Our aim is to characterise the genetic make-up of the [[United Kingdom|British]] population and relate this to the historical and archaeological evidence."'' The researchers presented some of their findings to the public via the [[Channel 4]] television series "Faces of Britain." On 14 April 2007, Channel 4 in [[UK|Britain]] aired a program that highlighted the study’s then-current findings. The project took [[DNA]] samples from hundreds of volunteers throughout Britain, seeking tell-tale fragments of DNA that would reveal the biological traces of successive waves of colonisers — [[Celt]]s, [[Saxons]], [[Vikings]], etc. — in various parts of Britain. The findings showed that the [[Viking]] invasion of Britain was predominantly from Danish Vikings while the [[Orkney Islands]] were settled by Norwegian Vikings.

He is currently{{when|date=October 2015}} Head of the [[Cancer]] and Immunogenetics [[Laboratory]] in the Weatherall Institute of Molecular Medicine at the [[University of Oxford]]. [[Research]] interests of the laboratory include the fundamental [[genetics]] and [[biology]] of [[colorectal cancer]].

==Honours and awards==
Bodmer has won numerous awards including:
{{colbegin||35em}}
*[[List of Fellows of the Royal Society elected in 1974|1974: Fellow of the Royal Society]] <ref name=royal/><ref name=royal2>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151009144644/https://royalsociety.org/people/walter-bodmer-11105/|archivedate=2015-10-09|url=https://royalsociety.org/people/walter-bodmer-11105/|title=Sir Walter Bodmer FMedSci FRS|publisher=[[Royal Society]]|location=London}}</ref>
*1980: [[William Allan Award]]
*1986: Knighted
*1987: [[Ellison–Cliffe Lecture|Ellison-Cliffe Medal]] from the [[Royal Society of Medicine]].
*1988: Honorary Degree (Doctor of Science) from the [[University of Bath]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.bath.ac.uk/ceremonies/hongrads/ |title=Honorary Graduates 1989 to present | publisher = [[University of Bath]] |work=bath.ac.uk |accessdate=18 February 2012}}</ref>
*1994: [[Michael Faraday Prize]]
*2013: [[Royal Medal]] from the Royal Society
* 1984: delivered the [[Royal Institution Christmas Lectures|Royal Institution Christmas Lecture]] on ''The Message of the Genes''.
{{colend}}
His certifcate of election to the Royal Society reads: {{centered pull quote|Distinguished for his theoretical and experimental contributions to genetics. His analyses of population genetics models, especially human, his contribution to the understanding of bacterial transformation, to the understanding of the HL-A system, and to the use of somatic cell hybrids for human linkage studies are outstanding. Few scientists have contributed distinguished work in such a range of fields, and involving such a range of experience of techniques, mathematical and experimental, and such a range of organisms.<ref name=royal>{{cite web |url=https://collections.royalsociety.org/DServe.exe?dsqIni=Dserve.ini&dsqApp=Archive&dsqDb=Catalog&dsqCmd=show.tcl&dsqSearch=(RefNo==%27EC%2F1974%2F01%27) |title = EC/1974/01: Bodmer, Walter Fred |publisher=The Royal Society |archivedate=2015-04-11 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Xi6DQc4O  |location=London}}</ref>}}

==Personal life==
Bodmer's father was Jewish so the family were obliged to leave Germany in 1938 and settled in [[Manchester]].  In 1956 Bodmer married [[Julia Bodmer|Julia Bodmer (née Pilkington) 1934 – 2001 ]] a British geneticist.  They had three children.<ref name=whoswho/>
